In answer to your letter of November 15, I think that Harley's idea
for NAEB to set up a national audience survey office in Washington, D. C.
is essentially a good one. The only question I guess I would have is why
such an office should be limited to "conducting surveys for local stations
to determine the special requirements and wants of their audiences". I am
sure that this is a legitimate and often helpful kind of research activity
but I would think that an organization which was set up with broader research
aims and development might be better than one which was limited to audience
research alone.
In terms of developing a possible NAEB research center, I think it
might also be well to consider the stated interest in research which has
recently come from NAB. President Collins of NAB, I believe, has set up a
committee (with McGannon as chairman me thinks) which is presently discussÂ¬
ing a NAB sponsored Research and Training Center. This committee is now
engaged in some conference and discussion regarding the research needs and
problems in broadcasting and whether such a center should be established at
some university or in Washington, D. C. or some other metropolitan area.
The Association for Professional Broadcasting Education has been quite
interested and active in this NAB development. If NAEB is going to develop
a research center, I think it might be well for Bill Harley to consult with
and perhaps coordinate activity with Bruce Linton, President of APBE at the
University of Kansas and/or with someone who is involved with the parent
NAB Research Committee.
